newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: U.S. urges Slovakia to finish kidnap probe.
newsitem.headline: U.S. urges Slovakia to finish kidnap probe.

text.p: The U.S. ambassador to Slovakia warned on Tuesday that Bratislava would harm its chances of joining NATO and the European Union if it failed to clear up a tangled set of criminal cases with political links.
The cases centre on Michal Kovac Junior, adult son of President Michal Kovac, who was kidnapped in August 1995, bundled into the boot of his car and dumped outside a police station in Austria.

Opposition politicians have attributed the kidnapping to a feud between the president and Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar. Two state detectives were sacked after voicing suspicions that the SIS secret service was involved.
According to a ex-policeman named Robert Remias, a former SIS member told him the abduction was organised by SIS chief Ivan Lexa, an ally of the prime minister.
But Remias, the only contact with the former SIS source, was killed by a car bomb and another investigator adjourned the case in May due to lack of evidence.
U.S. Ambassador Ralph Johnson told the independent Slovak Foreign Policy Association that dropping the probe would damage the country's hopes of joining Western institutions.

"We make no judgments about the outcome of these investigations, but abandoning them would in our view be very damaging to Slovakia's candidacy," Johnson said in an address in Presov, according to a text released by the embassy in Bratislava.
